TRACIE BARNARD
Let's Talk About it Girl's Home III
615 W. Lovell,
Kalamazoo, MI, 49007
Re: License #: CI390403045
Investigation: 2023C0000173
Dear Ms. BARNARD:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (734) 395-0920.
Sincerely,
Rorie Dodge-Pifer, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
235 Grand, Ste 1305
P.O. Box 30037
Lansing, MI 48909

P.O. BOX 30037 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
***This report contains sexually implicit information***
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CI390403045
Licensee Group Organization: Let's Talk About It CMH Services, PLLC
Licensee Designee: ELIAKIM R. THORPE
Chief Administrator: TRACIE BARNARD
Agency Name: Let's Talk About it Girl's Home III
Agency Address: 615 W. Lovell
Kalamazoo, MI 49007
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 09/17/2024
Capacity: 14

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Staff Qualifications
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
(b) Experience to perform the duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
2

Allegation Youth was AWOL on 1/13/23 and left a note in their room stating
they had sexual intercourse with a person that has the same
name as a staff member that worked at the facility for 60 days.
Investigation A complaint was received on 1/17/23 alleging Youth A had gone
AWOL on 01/13/2023. In her room was a note stating that she had
sex with Staff 1. She did not write Staff 1's last name on this note,
but Staff 1 was the only Staff 1 in this facility. This note appeared
to be in Youth A's handwriting. When Youth A returned from
AWOL she denied that it was Staff 1 but was someone with the
same first name as Staff 1. Staff 1 was contacted and he denied
this as well. Staff 1 had been terminated two weeks ago and he
had worked there less than 60 days.
Interviews:
The Licensee Designee (LD) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 1/18/23. LD reported she asked Youth A about Staff 1
after they found the note she made saying she had sex with
someone of the same name. LD stated they had to talk to Staff 1
previously about his boundaries. He bought Youth B gifts for
Christmas and they talked to him about not buying things for just
one youth. LD said they were doing room searches and they
found a journal with the message in it. LD reported she called
Staff 1 and asked him about it and Staff 1 denied it was him. LD
then told Staff 1 not to have contact with the girls. LD said they do
have males working in the girls home, but the males are always
paired with a female staff and males are not to be alone with the
girls.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 1/18/23 in
collaboration with the DHHS Worker. Youth A reported she has
not had a relationship with Staff 1. She reported the staff found a
note that said she had sex with someone with Staff 1's name.
Youth A stated Staff 1 is too old for her. She said she does see a
boy with the same name as Staff 1 and that was who she was
referring to. She reported she was cool with Staff 1, but not
inappropriate.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 1/18/23. Staff
2 stated she was going through the girls’ rooms and cleaning
them. While she was in Youth A's room she found a journal. Staff
2 said she went through the journal due to Youth A being AWOL
at the time. She opened the journal up and found the entry about
someone with Staff 1's name. Staff 2 reported she worked with
Staff 1 and he made her feel uncomfortable. He would ask Staff 2
personal questions and on Christmas Day he brought in gifts for
Youth B. Staff 2 said the girls in the house would tell her that Staff
3

1 favors Youth B. She said Staff 1 would tell Youth A and Youth B
if they had problems with the other staff to tell staff that "[Staff 1]
said…"
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility by the DHHS
Worker on 1/31/23. This consultant participated by phone. Youth
B remembered Staff 1. She said he worked all different shifts. She
got along well with him. She respected him and did what she was
supposed to do so he favored her. She said she received gifts like
make-up from Staff 1. He would let her have things the other girls
could not have. Youth B said there was nothing inappropriate
going on and nothing inappropriate was said. Youth B reported
Youth A tells her the boys she sees but she does not give names.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility by the DHHS
Worker on 1/31/23. This consultant participated by phone. Youth
C stated there has not been any inappropriate relationships
between youth and staff at the facility. She said she remembered
Staff 1. She said he was not inappropriate, and he did not have
favorite youth. She reported the male staff cannot walk into a
room by themselves. A female staff has to be with them. Youth C
said she never heard Youth A say she was seeing someone with
Staff 1's name.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility along with the
DHHS Worker on 1/31/23. This consultant participated by phone.
Staff 4 reported she worked with Staff 1 for part of their shift and
that was it. She did not see anything inappropriate about him or
that he favored any of the girls. The girls would say he favored
Youth B, but she did not know if this was true. Staff 4 said Youth A
never mentioned seeing anyone with Staff 1's name. Youth A did
tell them she liked men in their 20's.
Staff 1 was interviewed by telephone on 2/14/23. He stated he first
heard of the allegations against him by LD who asked him about
them. He denied having a sexual relationship with Youth A. LD
called him back later and told him Youth A denied it was him she
mentioned in the note. Staff 1 reported he usually worked 8am to
8pm and sometimes went in at 3pm to help out. He said he was
always scheduled with a female staff. If he had to wake the girls
up in the morning he would knock on their bedroom door. He said
he would never go into their rooms.
During a case conference with the DHHS Worker on 2/8/23 she
reported she did not have any findings. She also reported the local
4

police had completed their investigation and were not filing
charges.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A Safety Plan: This included provisions for keeping
Youth A from going AWOL it did not address interaction
with Staff 1 as Staff 1 no longer worked at the facility.
• Youth A Case File: Youth A was admitted to the program
on 9/14/22 for step-down from another facility. She has a
history of AWOL and being oppositional. Since being
admitted to the program Youth A has gone AWOL on many
occasions.
• Staff 1 File: Staff 1 is 25 years old. He was hired on
10/23/22. He received training in the facility's policies and
procedures when hired. During his time at the facility, he
was disciplined for sleeping while on shift and having poor
boundaries with the youth. He was terminated on 1/12/23
due to poor job performance. Documentation indicated
Staff 1 told the youth at the facility they could call him.
• Boundaries Policy: Male staff at the girl’s home are to be
scheduled with a female staff and male staff are not to be
unsupervised on the second floor during sleeping hours.
The policy also states dating and sexual relationships
between employees and youth are strictly prohibited.
• Youth A Journal Entry: "Mr. [Staff 1] has started to act
funny. I don't know what I did wrong. He said my pussy was
tight and I gave him grate (sic) head, but now he act like it
never even happened."
Analysis Staff 1 and Youth A both deny the two of them were having a
sexual relationship and there is nothing from other interviews to
indicate anything sexual occurred between the two.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4157 Behavior management.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies and
Description procedures that describe the institution’s behavior management
system. The policies and procedures shall be reviewed annually
and updated as needed. These shall be available to all residents,
their families, and referring agencies.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On this same date, when youth returned, they were scratched by
a staff member trying to confiscate their cell phone.
Investigation Another complaint received on 1/17/23 alleged when Youth A
returned to the house after being AWOL the Chief Administrator
(CA) scratched Youth A on her hand when CA confiscated Youth
5

A's cell phone. Youth A is not supposed to have a cell phone.
After Youth A was scratched, she put hand sanitizer on her hand
and it burned. No scratches were observed on Youth A's hand.
Interviews:
The complainant is the Chief Operating Officer (COO) at the
facility. She reported she was on the telephone with the Licensee
Designee (LD) when Youth A told her about the scratch from CA.
She said she was not present when the incident occurred.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 1/18/23 in
collaboration with the DHHS Worker. Youth A reported the Chief
Administrator (CA) snatched her phone out of her hand because
Youth A would not give it to her. Youth A stated CA told the staff
to follow Youth A when she left the house. The staff told CA no, so
CA followed her. Youth A said that while they were in front of the
neighbor's house CA snatched Youth A's phone out of her hand.
Youth A left and another staff followed her. The police then came.
Youth A said she returned to the house then left again as soon as
the police left. Youth A stated she runs away because she is
bored at the facility. They do not get to do fun age-appropriate
activities. She also wants to be on her phone, but it is not allowed.
CA was interviewed face to face at the facility in collaboration with
the DHHS Worker on 1/18/23. CA reported she received a call
from staff telling her the girls were refusing to go to bed and two of
the girls were in the bathroom smoking marijuana. When CA
arrived at the facility the two girls came out and Youth A prepared
to go AWOL. CA stated when Youth A got to the sidewalk in front
of the house she confronted her. Youth A pulled her cell phone out
and dropped it so CA grabbed it. CA said she held the phone to
her body as Youth A tried to pry it out of her hand. CA clarified
that she was faced away from Youth A so Youth A wrapped her
arms around CA. The police were called then Youth A took off. CA
reported a staff member followed Youth A until the police arrived
and were able to convince Youth A to return to the house. Once
the police were gone Youth A went AWOL. CA reported she never
touched Youth A and said Youth A was the one touching her. She
said she had an opportunity to grab the phone that Youth A was
not supposed to have so she did. CA clarified that they had been
unsuccessful at getting the phone from Youth A because she
would not participate in searches.
LD was interviewed face to face at the facility on 1/18/23. She
reported Youth A told her CA grabbed her phone out of her hand
and scratched her. LD said she took pictures but there was no
6

scratch. LD said she was on the phone with the COO at the time
so the COO called in the allegation.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on 1/31/23.
This consultant participated by phone. Youth B said she did not
witness the interaction between Youth A and CA.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility by the DHHS
Worker on 1/31/23. This consultant participated by phone. Youth
C reported no one was ever hurt by a staff member. Youth A told
her she was scratched by CA but Youth C did not see the incident.
Documents Reviewed:
• CA Employee File: CA was hired in July of 2022. She did
not have any disciplines in her file.
• Contraband Policy: Youth are not to have cell phones at the
facility.
• Search Policy: Youth will be given a gown and a clear
plastic bag so their items can be search upon return to the
facility.
• Pictures: Pictures of Youth A's hand did not show any
scratches.
• Police Report: A police report from 1/12/23 was reviewed.
The report addressed Youth A trying to run away and the
officer’s interaction with her. The reports from both CA and
Youth A were the same as the information disclosed in their
interviews. Staff 3 reported to the police that she saw Youth
A trying to get a phone from CA.
Analysis The facility is compliant. CA reported Youth A dropped the phone
and CA picked it up. The pictures and reports from CA and LD
indicate CA did not snatch the phone from Youth A nor did she
scratch Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149
Section (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible meals
Description daily unless medically contraindicated and documented.
(2) Meals shall be of sufficient quantity to meet the nutritional
allowances recommended by USDA
guidelines:(www.healthierus.gov/dietaryguidelines)
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The youth at the facility reported they only eat hot dogs and
noodles and there is no milk in the facility.
Investigation During the above investigations Youth A's Foster Care Worker
(FCW) and the FCW Supervisor had a virtual meeting with this
7

consultant on 1/20/23. They reported Youth A expressed concerns
about the food at the facility. Youth A told FCW that she is only
allowed to have 8oz of milk a day. She further alleged the staff eat
their food they get from the food bank leaving less for the girls.
Youth A told them here are mushrooms growing under the kitchen
sink.
Interviews:
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility by the DHHS
Worker on 1/31/23. This consultant participated by phone. Youth
B was asked about the food at the facility. She said the food was
terrible. They have a lot of hot dogs and noodles. She claimed
they have not had milk for 2 weeks. They can get snacks out of
the snack basket, but it is food no one wants. Youth B said they
do not have what is on the menu. The girls prepare their own food
for breakfast and on days they are home for lunch. She said some
staff will cook dinner and some staff do not. She further reported
the staff do not eat with the girls, and they make food they bring
with them.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility by the DHHS
Worker on 1/31/23. This consultant participated by phone. Youth
C reported all the food they get is expired. She indicated the
peanut butter, jelly, and donuts they were fed had all expired. She
said they eat the same food every day because the menu is a
joke. They have to eat Ramen noodles and hotdogs every day.
She reported yesterday for dinner they ate rice and corn. They did
not have any meat. She said some of the staff eat with the girls.
Youth C said she eats alone because she does not want to eat
around others. She reported the staff bring in their own food to
prepare and the staff do not eat the girls food. Youth C said they
do not have eggs, real milk, butter, or cheese in the house. For
snack they have fruit and peanuts. She said the majority of the
staff will cook for the girls but some do not. She said the girls do
not mind making their own food.
A phone call was placed to CA on 2/1/23. She stated the facility
had just run out of milk. The staff do an inventory every week and
they go shopping for those items on Wednesdays. CA said the
staff do the shopping. They are given gift cards and go out and
buy the items then turn in their receipts. She also said staff create
the menu and CA signs off on it. This is done weekly. The staff
cook whatever is on the menu. CA said they do provide
alternatives for the youth who have dietary restrictions. She said
the staff do not eat the food.
8

A phone call was placed to LD on 2/1/23. She was informed of the
allegations. She reported because the girls will eat everything at
all different hours of the day they will keep items upstairs that they
do not want the girls to access. Then when it is needed they will
bring it down. LD was asked why the DHHS Worker and this
consultant were not shown the food on the 3rd floor during the
visits on 1/31 and 2/1, and she stated there probably was not any
food up there at the time. She said she will go to Sam's and take
staff with her. She reported they have been advised by a dietitian
on what foods to provide.
Staff 2 was interviewed by telephone on 2/13/23. She reported the
facility has plenty of food but the girls are picky and choose not to
eat what is provided. She said the milk the facility provides is not
good and the girls do not like it. They almost always have milk in
the house. If they are missing something they just call an
administrator and someone will bring them what they need.
Staff 1 was interviewed by telephone on 2/14/23. In regards to the
food he stated there was food in the house but it was not food the
girls wanted to eat. He stated it was more like detention food.
Staff 3 was interviewed via three-way phone call along with the
DHHS Worker on 2/7/23. Staff 3 reported she did not have any
concerns about the food at the facility. It was hard to keep the girls
on the schedule. She clarified that the girls wait to eat when they
are supposed to be sleeping. She said they are trying to stop the
girls from overeating so there will be enough food for everyone.
She said the girls are also picky about what they eat.
A phone call was received from an anonymous staff (AS) member.
She stated currently the facility is doing better with having food
available for the girls however prior to this change the girls were
eating the same items every day. She stated it was like the girls
were in jail. Staff cooked what was on the menu, but the girls
would not eat the meals because they were not meals they liked.
AS reported, she herself would not eat most of the meals they
provided. She said the girls complain about the food all the time. If
the girls did not want what was on the menu, they could not eat
anything else. AS reported milk was not always available. She
said even though the facility would have the ingredients for the
menu items they would not have enough other supplies like pans,
tissue, and soap. Staff would have to ask several times for
supplies. AS said she had to get supplies herself so the girls
would not go without.
9

On-site Inspections:
The DHHS Worker inspected the refrigerator and pantry while she
was at the facility on 1/31/23. She forwarded pictures showing a
lack of food and milk in the refrigerator.
An unannounced on-site visit was completed on 2/1/2023 at 8am
by this consultant. The Case Manager (CM) was present at the
time. The menu was viewed hanging on the refrigerator. The
menu start date was 1/30/23. No other menus were viewed. The
menu stated pears and Poptarts were for breakfast. The
refrigerator in the kitchen held 3 gallons of milk, dishes of
leftovers, a mostly empty bag of salad, and yogurts. The freezer
had frozen meat and fries. On the counter were two baskets of
food which contained Ramon noodles, peanut butter, jelly,
peanuts, tomato soup, rice, and beans. The pantry held cans of
soup, jelly, noodles, cereal, canned beans, canned vegetables, 1
bag of hamburger buns and 1 loaf of bread. Basement freezer
held 2 freezer meals, many hot dogs, cranberries, various frozen
chicken. CM reported today is their grocery shopping day. She
stated she was not present for breakfast but said they would have
had canned pears. One youth was still in bed and no pears were
located in the house. She stated maybe they were on the third
floor where the offices are. She said they keep some food items
there. She stated the youth do not have access to that floor. She
reported CA is in charge of the menu and making the grocery list.
She stated the girls are allowed to have input in the menu. The 3rd
floor was not viewed as it was only brought up after this consultant
finished the tour and was leaving.
Another unannounced on-site visit occurred on 2/7/23. CA was
present for the visit. There were two menus on the fridge. One
menu was specifically for Youth B and a food plan for Youth C
who had recently been diagnosed as pre-diabetic. The refrigerator
had leftovers, yogurt, and eggs. There were small plastic jars of
milk for the girls to drink. CA stated when the girls drink their entire
bottle of milk the staff can get them more milk. She said they did
this because one of the girls would dink out of the carton and the
other girls did not like it. CA also stated they have begun to keep
track of what the girls eat on the communication logs. CA showed
the food that was stored on the third floor. Mostly dry food and a
box of shelf stable milk was observed. CA reported the box of milk
had been at the facility when the DHHS Worker checked for milk
on 1/31/23 but she was unable to find it because it was in the back
of the closet behind a box. The snack baskets on the counter were
full and included fresh fruit.
10

Another unannounced visit to the facility occurred on 2/14/23. The
refrigerator was full of food. The cupboards had supplies for
cooking food, spices, and baking supplies. There was no
mushrooms or fungus growing under the kitchen counter. There
was an up-to-date menu and Youth C's food plan on the
refrigerator. The snack baskets were full and included fresh fruit.
Documents Reviewed:
• Weekly Menus: Various menus for the last 2 months were
reviewed. The menus included all food groups and
appropriate food items for the girls. All menus were
completed and ran for a week.
• Communication Logs: the logs indicated the youth were
eating a variety of food. Even when they refused the menu
items they were still eating other items. Those items were
usually hot dogs and noodles and were chosen by the girls.
The logs were compared with the menus and the food
eaten by the girls on days they did not refuse were the
same as the menu items.
• Pictures from 1/31/23: The DHHS Worker’s pictures were
reviewed. The pictures did show a lack of food in the
kitchen and a lack of variety of food in the pantry. There
was no milk pictured. None of the pictures were of the 3rd
floor pantry and refrigerator.
• Pictures from LD: LD sent pictures late on 2/1/23 of the
snack baskets to show they had been restocked with fresh
fruit. She also provided pictures of notes posted for staff on
a bulletin board telling staff to refill the snack baskets and
milk containers every day.
• Receipts: Receipts from 4 different stores showing food
purchased throughout the last month. Two of those receipts
were bulk food that was purchased. There were also two
receipts from the food bank. All receipts showed purchases
of fresh meat, frozen meat, eggs, fresh fruit, cereal, and
various other items. Receipts also indicated tissue and
soap were purchased.
• Dietary Guidelines for Americans: the federal government’s
most recent dietary guidelines were reviewed. A
comparison of the guidelines and the facilities menus found
the facility is providing an adequate diet for the girls.
• E-mail from Youth B’s Foster Care Worker on 2/8/23: Youth
B did report to her that she did not like the food that the
staff cooked for them. She created a safety plan to ensure
Youth B was getting enough food. In the safety plan the
Foster Care Worker said she saw adequate food when she
visited the facility on 2/6/23.
11

• E-mails from Youth C’s Foster Care Worker on 2/8 and 2/9:
Youth C indicated to her that they now have food but there
had been a lack of food previously. She was at the facility
prior to seeing the allegations on 2/2 and saw fruit and
bread on the counter. She also reported a contractor doing
an assessment on Youth C saw staff bring in groceries on
2/3. The contractor told the Foster Care Worker there was
an abundance of hot dogs brought in as well as other food
items.
Analysis While the visits on 1/31/23 and 2/1/23 indicated a lack of food
there was enough food in the pantry and freezer to get the girls by
until groceries were purchased on 2/1/23. Once the facility
administration was aware they did not have milk they went right
out and purchased some. Interviews indicated the girls were not
going without food but rather where being provided with food they
did not like. Further, interviews indicated the staff are not eating
the girl’s food.
Technical Assistance: Work with the girls to create a menu of food
they will want to eat, provide fresh fruit, and continue to document
what the girls are eating on each shift.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that this facility’s license be unchanged.
2/17/23
_____________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Pifer Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
03/09/2023

Area Manager
